title: 115_hr2493
content: The Act may be cited as the "Conflicts from Political Fundraising Act of 2017". Congress finds that public confidence in the Federal Government relies on officers and employees avoiding conflicts of interest. The risk arises when nominees or appointees have ties to political entities. Since the Citizens United v. FEC decision in 2010, corporate spending under Federal laws has increased. Since the 2010 Citizens United v. FEC decision, corporate political spending has significantly increased, with some contributions being made anonymously through entities organized under section 501(c)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. This anonymity poses a risk of conflicts of interest, whether the spending is public or undisclosed. Financial disclosure requirements currently do not mandate reporting of donations to political action committees or entities. Current financial disclosure requirements do not mandate reporting of funds donated to political action committees or entities organized under section 501(c)(4) or section 501(c)(6) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
